channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Clean Energy Projects Surge After Climate Bill Passage
item.description: Investments in battery factories, solar panel manufacturing and mining will help the Biden administration meet targets for reducing greenhouse gases.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing and Ivan Penn
item.media:credit: David Walter Banks for The New York Times
item.media:description: An electric battery plant in Commerce, Ga., operated by SK Battery America. Other companies have announced investments in similar factories in recent weeks.

item.title: Trump Special Master Ruling Lifts Profile of Judge Aileen Cannon
item.description: Judge Aileen M. Cannon has issued the first highly scrutinized ruling of her short judicial career, involving the person who put her on the bench: former President Donald J. Trump.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei, Maggie Haberman and Alan Feuer
item.media:credit: Josh Ritchie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Judge Aileen M. Cannon granted former President Donald J. Trump’s request to appoint a special master to review materials seized from Mar-a-Lago, his private Florida club.

item.title: Special Masters and the Trump Records Investigation, Explained
item.description: An independent arbiter’s review of government documents seized at the former president’s home could significantly delay the criminal inquiry.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.media:credit: Hannah Beier for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Florida judge emphasized Donald J. Trump’s status as a former president in granting his request for a special master.

item.title: Video Raises Concerns About Election Data Breach in Georgia County
item.description: Surveillance video from rural Coffee County, Ga., raised new questions about the extent to which election data was improperly shared with pro-Trump figures challenging the 2020 election results.
item.dc:creator: Richard Fausset and Sean Keenan
item.media:credit: Coffee County Elections Office
item.media:description: In footage from Jan. 7, 2021, obtained by The Times, Cathy Latham, bottom, at the time the chair of the Coffee County Republican Party, welcomes a team of SullivanStrickler data scientists.

item.title: California narrowly averts electricity crisis as it sets records for energy use amid scorching heat.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Hubler, Kellen Browning, Ivan Penn and Jill Cowan
item.media:credit: Rachel Bujalski for The New York Times
item.media:description: An attempt to cool off during the extreme heat in Sacramento on Tuesday.

item.title: Sir Tom Stoppard Returns to New York With ‘Leopoldstadt’
item.description: After years of living “as if without history,” the playwright belatedly reckons with his Jewish roots, and his guilt, in “Leopoldstadt,” his most autobiographical play.
item.dc:creator: Maureen Dowd
item.media:credit: Charlie Gates for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I don’t recall ever consciously resisting finding out about myself,” Stoppard said. “It’s worse than that. I wasn’t actually interested. I was never curious enough. I just looked in one direction: forward.”

item.title: Bannon to Surrender to New York Authorities to Face Sealed Indictment
item.description: After President Donald J. Trump pardoned him in a case connected to a crowd-funded border wall, the Manhattan district attorney’s office opened its own investigation.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Davis O’Brien
item.media:credit: Lexey Swall for The New York Times
item.media:description: Stephen K. Bannon, pardoned by former President Donald Trump in 2021, is turning himself in.

item.title: How Russian Natural Gas Exports to Europe Have Changed Since the War
item.description: The fuel that once flowed freely has been abruptly reduced, sending prices soaring and forcing European governments to struggle for solutions.
item.dc:creator: Jason Karaian and Karl Russell
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Democrats Fret as Stacey Abrams Struggles in Georgia Governor’s Race
item.description: She has been trailing her Republican rival, Gov. Brian Kemp, alarming Democrats who have celebrated her as the master strategist behind the state’s Democratic shift.
item.dc:creator: Maya King and Reid J. Epstein
item.media:credit: David Walter Banks for The New York Times
item.media:description: Stacey Abrams has worked for years to register and turn out Democratic voters, helping to fuel victories by President Biden and two senators in the 2020 election cycle.

item.title: Maura Healey Could Make History in Run for Massachusetts Governor
item.description: Ms. Healey and another Democrat running for governor of Oregon could become the first two openly lesbian governors in the country if they win in the fall.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck and Maggie Astor
item.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times
item.media:description: Maura Healey, left, who is running for governor, and Andrea Campbell, a candidate for attorney general, in Mattapan, Mass., on Tuesday.

item.title: At Head Start, Masks Remain On, Despite CDC Guidelines
item.description: Some of the nation’s poorest pre-K students are the last still under mask mandates, affecting enrollment.
item.dc:creator: Dana Goldstein
item.media:credit: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times
item.media:description: Melissa Ruiz with her children Gabriel, 3, left, and Milani, 4, at a Head Start center in Perth Amboy, N.J., where there are mandatory masking rules for teachers and children as young as 2.

item.title: The Great U.S. Open Ball Debate of 2022
item.description: The Open is the only Grand Slam tournament where women use different balls than men, and the Wilson ‘regular-duty’ ball has gotten into some players’ heads.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Futterman
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: The tennis balls used by women at the U.S. Open have played faster than those used by the men.

item.title: Frances Tiafoe Has Them Talking About Tennis in Freetown, Sierra Leone
item.description: Tiafoe, whose parents emigrated from the war-torn country before he was born, is the youngest American man to reach a U.S. Open quarterfinal in 16 years, and he has enough talent for two nations.
item.dc:creator: David Waldstein
item.media:credit: Angela Weiss/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Frances Tiafoe’s career has been defined by high expectations, plateaus, self-analysis and improvement.

item.title: Nick Kyrgios’s U.S. Open Run Ends One Match After Beating the Top Seed
item.description: Karen Khachanov of Russia needed five sets to put Kyrgios away, 7-5, 4-6, 7-5, 6-7, 6-4. He will play Casper Rudd of Norway in the semifinals on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Futterman
item.media:credit: Jason Szenes/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Nick Kyrgios of Australia throwing his racket during his quarterfinal match against Karen Khachanov of Russia. He slammed another one after the match.

item.title: Desert Winemaking ‘Sounds Absurd,’ but Israeli Vineyards in Negev Show the Way
item.description: As vintners around the world battle extreme heat and climate change, the pioneers producing wine in Israel’s arid south are testing ideas that might soon find global application.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Picking grenache grapes at sunrise in the Negev Desert this summer.

item.title: Is the Democratic Midterm Surge Overrated? Why Republicans Can Still Win the House and Senate.
item.description: The Dobbs ruling and falling gas prices may have shifted the narrative. But the G.O.P.’s chances in the midterms still look good.
item.dc:creator: Ross Douthat, Kristen Soltis Anderson and Erick Erickson
item.media:credit: Mark Peterson for The New York Times

item.title: How Michigan Resisted Far Right Extremism
item.description: Michigan may hold lessons for residents of other states looking to withstand the tide of authoritarianism and violence.
item.dc:creator: Barbara McQuade
item.media:credit: Seth Herald/Reuters
item.media:description: Militia members inside the Michigan State Capitol in 2020 protesting the extension of Gov. Gretchen Whitmer's Covid emergency stay-at-home order.

item.title: Brazil’s Bolsonaro Is Preparing for a Revolution
item.description: To stay in power, Brazil’s president may rely on his most fervent supporters.
item.dc:creator: Miguel Lago
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Adriano Machado/Reuters

item.title: What Should High Schoolers Read?
item.description: Kaitlyn Greenidge and Esau McCaulley on why America’s schools can’t get on the same page about required reading lists.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Argument’
item.media:credit: Dmitry Marchenko/EyeEm, via Getty Images

item.title: With Malice Toward Quite a Few
item.description: When it comes to saving democracy, Joe Biden slumps to the occasion.
item.dc:creator: Bret Stephens
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times

item.title: Education in America: School Is for Social Mobility
item.description: If politics is the art of the possible, perhaps the biggest silver lining of these past two years has been to redefine what is possible.
item.dc:creator: John N. Friedman
item.media:credit: Illustration by Chloe Scheffe; photographs by Internet Archive; the Met Collection; Jordan Graff and Robo Wunderkind, via Unsplash; and Calsidyrose and Vacuumfan7072, via Wikimedia Commons

item.title: When ‘Party Differences Are Not Fuzzy,’ Every State Is a Battleground
item.description: What is democracy? It depends on where you stand.
item.dc:creator: Thomas B. Edsall
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times

item.title: Colombia’s Petro Sees a Way Out of the Failed Drug War. Will the U.S. Cooperate?
item.description: The Biden administration’s new forward-thinking national policies are a step in the right direction, but the president must go further and end the global drug war.
item.dc:creator: Christy Thornton
item.media:credit: Ben Hickey

item.title: Chile’s Constitutional Fight Over Climate Change
item.description: Chileans rejected a proposed constitution that would have been the first to confront climate change. But they are not done.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Andreoni
item.media:credit: Rodrigo Sura/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Chileans voted to reject a new constitution on Sunday.

item.title: The Run-Up: The Stakes of the 2022 Midterm Elections
item.description: This November, Americans will head to the polls for the first major political test since Jan. 6.
item.media:credit: Photo illustration: The New York Times; Photo: Samuel Corum for The New York Times

item.title: Apple, the Ad Critic, Now Embraces Ads
item.description: Apple has long supported privacy and shunned those intrusive ads. What happens when it sells more ads, too?
item.dc:creator: Shira Ovide

item.title: Are You in a Moral Quandary?
item.description: We’d like to discuss it with you, live on Twitter Spaces, with the magazine’s Ethicist columnist, Kwame Anthony Appiah. Let us know below what’s troubling you.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Canada Stabbing Suspect Remains at Large After Manhunt in Saskatchewan
item.description: The police received reports that Myles Sanderson was spotted at the Indigenous reserve where the stabbings took place, but by day’s end he was not in custody, and an emergency alert was still in place for Saskatchewan.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen, Vjosa Isai and Yonette Joseph
item.media:credit: Amber Bracken for The New York Times
item.media:description: A police vehicle at James Smith Cree Nation after a report that Myles Sanderson may have been spotted there.

item.title: Seattle Storm’s Sue Bird Ends WNBA Career With Playoff Loss
item.description: Bird, 41, the Seattle Storm guard, had said she would retire after this season. The Storm fell to the Las Vegas Aces in the W.N.B.A. semifinals on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Shauntel Lowe
item.media:credit: Lindsey Wasson/Associated Press
item.media:description: Seattle Storm guard Sue Bird is retiring from the W.N.B.A. after 21 years. She became emotional as her home crowd cheered for her after the Storm lost to the Aces on Tuesday.

item.title: Blackpool Shows Challenges for New U.K. Leader Liz Truss
item.description: Blackpool contains one of the most deprived areas to turn to the Conservatives in Britain’s last general election. But with costs rising, there are already signs of cracks in that support.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Molly Darlington/Reuters
item.media:description: Blackpool Tower illuminated for the queen’s Platinum Jubilee celebrations this summer. The most daunting challenges Prime Minister Liz Truss will face will come in towns like Blackpool, England.

item.title: China’s Youth Try on the Communist Cadre Look
item.description: Why are some Chinese youth dressing like middle-aged civil servants? It might be ironic, or a longing for stability in uncertain times.
item.dc:creator: Joy Dong
item.media:credit: Li Xueren/Xinhua, via Associated Press
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping in his trademark blue jacket with oversize trousers during a July visit to Urumqi, China. The understated look has become surprisingly popular with some younger Chinese.

item.title: Can You Get Addicted to Melatonin?
item.description: The sleep supplement doesn’t cause physical dependence, but falling asleep without it can be tricky for some people.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Mike Ellis

item.title: How to Sleep During a Heat Wave
item.description: While it may be difficult to drift off when temperatures rise, there are things you can do to snooze more soundly.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Rabkin Peachman and Nicole Stock
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: Night Sweats Causes: Experts Explain Why You Sweat In Your Sleep
item.description: There are many possible reasons you might wake up in a pool of perspiration. Here’s how to tell when it should be cause for concern.
item.dc:creator: Alice Callahan
item.media:credit: Eric Helgas for The New York Times

item.title: Wide Awake at 3 A.M.? Readers Offer Advice on Insomnia
item.description: Well readers share a range of strategies they use to get back to sleep in the middle of the night.
item.dc:creator: Anahad O’Connor
item.media:credit: Dominic Kesterton

item.title: Javier Zamora Carried a Heavy Load. He Laid It to Rest on the Page.
item.description: Decades after traveling without his parents from El Salvador to the U.S. as a 9-year-old — a journey that almost killed him — Zamora describes the experience in a memoir.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin P. Russell
item.media:credit: Cassidy Araiza for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I don’t expect the people who are in the book to read it. But my dream scenario is that they open it,” Zamora said, “and see that there is this book out there thanking them.”
